title: China grants scholarships to two students from Brunei
description: On 26 August 2006, the diplomat from the Embassy of The People's Republic of China saw off two Brunei students at the airport, who have been awarded the full scholarship by the Chinese Government. The two students are from Maktab Sains Paduka Seri Begawan Sultan (MSPSBS), namely Pang Yi Jun and Pang Chia Cyn, and are the first batch awarded students.  Pang Yi Jun will major in Finance at Shanghai University of Finance & Economics and Pang Chia Cyn will major in  pharmacy at China Pharmacy University.  According to the Memorandum of Understanding on Cooperation in the Field of Higher Education between the Ministry of Eudcation of China and the Ministry of Education of Brunei Darussalam signed in 2004,  the Ministry of Education of China will provide two Bruneian students with full scholarships in China. Bruneian citizens can apply for a Bachelor's Degree, Master's Degree or further study of mandarin language and other professional/advanced courses.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
China grants scholarships to two students from Brunei

# Description
On 26 August 2006, the diplomat from the Embassy of The People's Republic of China saw off two Brunei students at the airport, who have been awarded the full scholarship by the Chinese Government. The two students are from Maktab Sains Paduka Seri Begawan Sultan (MSPSBS), namely Pang Yi Jun and Pang Chia Cyn, and are the first batch awarded students.  Pang Yi Jun will major in Finance at Shanghai University of Finance & Economics and Pang Chia Cyn will major in  pharmacy at China Pharmacy University.  According to the Memorandum of Understanding on Cooperation in the Field of Higher Education between the Ministry of Eudcation of China and the Ministry of Education of Brunei Darussalam signed in 2004,  the Ministry of Education of China will provide two Bruneian students with full scholarships in China. Bruneian citizens can apply for a Bachelor's Degree, Master's Degree or further study of mandarin language and other professional/advanced courses.
justification: Project involves educational scholarships without direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Scholarships for Bruneian students to study in China, focus on education and cultural exchange

title: 12th medical team dispatched to Muramvya Provincial Hospital
description: China has been sending medical teams to Burundi every two years since 1987. Qinghai Province has been responsible for sending the teams.   On March 28, 2006, the Chinese Government and the Government of Burundi signed an agreement on the dispatching of the 12th Chinese medical team to Burundi. The team included 29 members who were stationed at Muramvya Provincial Hospital. The team completed its term of service in Burundi from May 2006 to May 2008.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
12th medical team dispatched to Muramvya Provincial Hospital

# Description
China has been sending medical teams to Burundi every two years since 1987. Qinghai Province has been responsible for sending the teams.   On March 28, 2006, the Chinese Government and the Government of Burundi signed an agreement on the dispatching of the 12th Chinese medical team to Burundi. The team included 29 members who were stationed at Muramvya Provincial Hospital. The team completed its term of service in Burundi from May 2006 to May 2008.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical team dispatch, healthcare services at provincial hospital

description: In November 2006 during the Beijing Summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation (FOCAC), the Chinese Government donated $500,000 USD in cash to the Government of Burundi for unspecified purposes (p. 96).

title: Chinese Government dispatches 12th medical team to Praia Central Hospital
description: In 1984, Heilongjiang Province began sending medical teams to Cape Verde every two years. Then, in 1998, Sichuan Province, rather than Heilongjiang Province, began sending medical teams to Cape Verde ever two years. In 2006, the Chinese Government dispatched the 12th Chinese medical team (10th team from Sichuan Province) to Cape Verde. The 8-member team was stationed at Praia Central Hospital (Agostinho Neto Hospital or HAN) in the the capital city of Praia. It completed its term of service between September 2006 and September 2008.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches 12th medical team to Praia Central Hospital

# Description
In 1984, Heilongjiang Province began sending medical teams to Cape Verde every two years. Then, in 1998, Sichuan Province, rather than Heilongjiang Province, began sending medical teams to Cape Verde ever two years. In 2006, the Chinese Government dispatched the 12th Chinese medical team (10th team from Sichuan Province) to Cape Verde. The 8-member team was stationed at Praia Central Hospital (Agostinho Neto Hospital or HAN) in the the capital city of Praia. It completed its term of service between September 2006 and September 2008.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical team deployment to hospital, healthcare sector focus

title: China donates $100,000 USD to Cape Verde in response to bird flu in 2006
description: On August 31, 2006, China donated $100,000 USD in cash assistance to Cape Verde to help prevent the spread of bird flu. On this date, the cash assistance was officially handed over to Cape Verdean government through the signing of its handover certificate. This project is completed.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China donates $100,000 USD to Cape Verde in response to bird flu in 2006

# Description
On August 31, 2006, China donated $100,000 USD in cash assistance to Cape Verde to help prevent the spread of bird flu. On this date, the cash assistance was officially handed over to Cape Verdean government through the signing of its handover certificate. This project is completed.
justification: Project is a cash donation for public health purposes with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Cash assistance for bird flu prevention, health sector focus

title: Chinese Government Donates Container Scanning System to Cambodia in 2007
description: On April 8, 2006, the governments of China and Cambodia signed the Exchange of Letters agreement, "The Government of the People's Republic of China presents a container inspection to the Royal Government of Cambodia".  On April 28, 2006, the Ministry of Commerce of the People’s Republic of China discussed the tender mode of the Cambodia Container Inspection Equipment assistance project. The bidding method for the aid to Cambodia was studied and the Tender Committee decided to negotiate with Tsinghua Tongfang Weishi Technology Co., Ltd. (known as Nuchtech Company Ltd. in English) for the project.  On October 24, 2006, the aid agreement of the vehicle-mounted mobile container inspection equipment was signed by Li Jianmin, general manager of international business of Tsinghua Tongfang Weishi Company, and the Minister of Public Works and Transport of Cambodia, Sun Zhanto. On January 30, 2007, a ceremony was held at Phnom Penh to mark the official handover of the vehicle-mounted mobile container inspection equipment to the Royal Government of Cambodia. Cambodia hopes that such aid will help strengthen cargo security checks, help against smuggling and tax evasion, as well as modernize Cambodian custom clearance.   China has provided security scanning equipment to Cambodia several times. A donation of 3 container scanners and other security equipment was given in 2012 (see ProjectID#33076) and another four container scanners were given in 2013 (see ProjectID#33061).
combined_text:
# Sector
TRADE POLICIES AND REGULATIONS

# Title
Chinese Government Donates Container Scanning System to Cambodia in 2007

# Description
On April 8, 2006, the governments of China and Cambodia signed the Exchange of Letters agreement, "The Government of the People's Republic of China presents a container inspection to the Royal Government of Cambodia".  On April 28, 2006, the Ministry of Commerce of the People’s Republic of China discussed the tender mode of the Cambodia Container Inspection Equipment assistance project. The bidding method for the aid to Cambodia was studied and the Tender Committee decided to negotiate with Tsinghua Tongfang Weishi Technology Co., Ltd. (known as Nuchtech Company Ltd. in English) for the project.  On October 24, 2006, the aid agreement of the vehicle-mounted mobile container inspection equipment was signed by Li Jianmin, general manager of international business of Tsinghua Tongfang Weishi Company, and the Minister of Public Works and Transport of Cambodia, Sun Zhanto. On January 30, 2007, a ceremony was held at Phnom Penh to mark the official handover of the vehicle-mounted mobile container inspection equipment to the Royal Government of Cambodia. Cambodia hopes that such aid will help strengthen cargo security checks, help against smuggling and tax evasion, as well as modernize Cambodian custom clearance.   China has provided security scanning equipment to Cambodia several times. A donation of 3 container scanners and other security equipment was given in 2012 (see ProjectID#33076) and another four container scanners were given in 2013 (see ProjectID#33061).
justification: Project involves donation of security scanning equipment for customs purposes, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Container inspection equipment, focus on cargo security and customs modernization

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 250 million government concessional loan for Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA) Mobile Communication Network Project
description: On April 20, 2004, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cambodia signed an RMB 250 million ($30 million) preferential loan framework agreement. Cambodian Fi­nance Ministry Secretary of State Ouk Rabun and Chinese Vice Commerce Minister An Min signed on behalf of their respective governments. The agreement stipulated that China Eximbank would provide a concessional loan worth up to RMB 250 million to the Government of Cambodia (with a 2% interest rate and 20 year maturity). The agreement was signed with Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen during his 5-day visit to China (19-23 April 2004).  Then, on April 8, 2006, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia signed an RMB 250 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement — based upon the terms and conditions specified in the April 20, 2004 preferential loan framework agreement — for the Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA) Mobile Communication Network Project. The proceeds of the GCL were used by the Government of Cambodia to on-lend to a private company called AZ Distribution Co Ltd (also known as AZ Communication Company and Azcom) —  headed by a ruling party (CPP) parliamentarian named Ung Bun Hauv (Ung Bun Hov) — in order to establish a new mobile phone service in Cambodia. AZCOM was then supposed to use the loan proceeds to finance a $30 million commercial contract that it signed with with Huawei Technologies on September 28, 2005.  The purpose of the project and the commercial contract was to supply and install CDMA (Code Division Multiple Access) equipment and thereby support Azcom’s expansion efforts. At the time that the loan agreement was signed, opposition lawmaker Son Chhay argued that the deal risked wasting government funds. He said: “It’s a private company. We don’t understand the reason be­hind the government’s commitment to borrowing money from the Chinese for that company. We’re doubtful of how we’re going to benefit from it.” He also noted that Azcom appeared to be the “right hand” of the government. AidData has not identified any evidence that this project was implemented.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the AZCOM CDMA 2000 1X Project or the CDMA2000 Mobile Communication Network System Project. The Chinese project title is CDMA2000移动通讯网络系统项目.2. On August 4, 2005, Azcom received a license from Cambodia’s Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications to install the CDMA2000 system, thereby become the fifth mobile service provider in the country.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 250 million government concessional loan for Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA) Mobile Communication Network Project

# Description
On April 20, 2004, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cambodia signed an RMB 250 million ($30 million) preferential loan framework agreement. Cambodian Fi­nance Ministry Secretary of State Ouk Rabun and Chinese Vice Commerce Minister An Min signed on behalf of their respective governments. The agreement stipulated that China Eximbank would provide a concessional loan worth up to RMB 250 million to the Government of Cambodia (with a 2% interest rate and 20 year maturity). The agreement was signed with Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen during his 5-day visit to China (19-23 April 2004).  Then, on April 8, 2006, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia signed an RMB 250 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement — based upon the terms and conditions specified in the April 20, 2004 preferential loan framework agreement — for the Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA) Mobile Communication Network Project. The proceeds of the GCL were used by the Government of Cambodia to on-lend to a private company called AZ Distribution Co Ltd (also known as AZ Communication Company and Azcom) —  headed by a ruling party (CPP) parliamentarian named Ung Bun Hauv (Ung Bun Hov) — in order to establish a new mobile phone service in Cambodia. AZCOM was then supposed to use the loan proceeds to finance a $30 million commercial contract that it signed with with Huawei Technologies on September 28, 2005.  The purpose of the project and the commercial contract was to supply and install CDMA (Code Division Multiple Access) equipment and thereby support Azcom’s expansion efforts. At the time that the loan agreement was signed, opposition lawmaker Son Chhay argued that the deal risked wasting government funds. He said: “It’s a private company. We don’t understand the reason be­hind the government’s commitment to borrowing money from the Chinese for that company. We’re doubtful of how we’re going to benefit from it.” He also noted that Azcom appeared to be the “right hand” of the government. AidData has not identified any evidence that this project was implemented.
justification: Project focuses on mobile communication network development, which is unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: CDMA Mobile Communication Network Project, mobile phone service expansion, communication equipment installation

title: Chinese Embassy in Cambodia donates $15,000 USD for Chinese language courses in Cambodia
description: On September 26, 2006, the Chinese Embassy in Cambodia donated $15,000 USD to the Association of Khmer Chinese in Cambodia (AKCC). AKCC allocated the funds to help more than 70 primary and middle schools in Cambodia develop their Chinese language courses.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Embassy in Cambodia donates $15,000 USD for Chinese language courses in Cambodia

# Description
On September 26, 2006, the Chinese Embassy in Cambodia donated $15,000 USD to the Association of Khmer Chinese in Cambodia (AKCC). AKCC allocated the funds to help more than 70 primary and middle schools in Cambodia develop their Chinese language courses.
justification: Project focuses on language education without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation for Chinese language courses in Cambodian schools, education sector focus

title: Chinese Government donates 30 fire trucks to Cambodia
description: On April 8, 2006, China and Cambodia signed an Exchange of Notes Agreements to provide 30 firetrucks for Cambodia. On the afternoon of May 10, 2007, Cambodian Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of the Interior, Kennedy, personally presided over the handover of 30 fire engines to the Royal Government of Cambodia in the Cambodian capital of Phnom Penh. Mrs. Zhang Jinfeng, China's Ambassador to Cambodia, and Mr. Hok Lundy, National Police Chief of Cambodia, singed the Certificate of Delivery and Receipt on behalf of China and Cambodia respectively on May 14, 2007.  The donation is a follow-up to the pledge by the Chinese government to provide water pumps (see ProjectID#32127) and fire engines (as captured in this project) to Cambodia during the second summit of the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) in July 2005.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government donates 30 fire trucks to Cambodia

# Description
On April 8, 2006, China and Cambodia signed an Exchange of Notes Agreements to provide 30 firetrucks for Cambodia. On the afternoon of May 10, 2007, Cambodian Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of the Interior, Kennedy, personally presided over the handover of 30 fire engines to the Royal Government of Cambodia in the Cambodian capital of Phnom Penh. Mrs. Zhang Jinfeng, China's Ambassador to Cambodia, and Mr. Hok Lundy, National Police Chief of Cambodia, singed the Certificate of Delivery and Receipt on behalf of China and Cambodia respectively on May 14, 2007.  The donation is a follow-up to the pledge by the Chinese government to provide water pumps (see ProjectID#32127) and fire engines (as captured in this project) to Cambodia during the second summit of the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) in July 2005.
justification: Project involves donation of fire trucks for public safety purposes, unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Donation of 30 fire trucks to Cambodia for public safety purposes

title: China signed agreement with Cambodia to provide Anti-Malaria Medicine
description: On September 13, 2006, the Chinese government signed an agreement with Cambodia on its assistance in preventing the spread of malaria in the Kingdom as well as in providing  anti-malarial drugs. The agreement is signed by China Ambassador to Cambodia Zhang Jinfeng and Cambodian Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation Hor Namhong.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China signed agreement with Cambodia to provide Anti-Malaria Medicine

# Description
On September 13, 2006, the Chinese government signed an agreement with Cambodia on its assistance in preventing the spread of malaria in the Kingdom as well as in providing  anti-malarial drugs. The agreement is signed by China Ambassador to Cambodia Zhang Jinfeng and Cambodian Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation Hor Namhong.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare provision with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Provision of anti-malarial drugs and assistance in preventing malaria spread
